concept: Every pipeline stage starts with a focused interview before AI generation. Each stage has its own set of questions tailored to what that stage needs to produce. The interview is the INPUT, the structured editor is the OUTPUT.

questions.question: What are you building?
questions.subtext: Describe your product in 1-3 sentences.

questions.question: Who is this for?
questions.subtext: Describe the specific people who will use this. What's their role, skill level, and current pain?

questions.question: What problems does this solve?
questions.subtext: List the frustrations or gaps your users face today.

questions.question: What are the must-have features?
questions.subtext: Core features for day one. Not nice-to-haves.

questions.question: What do people use today instead?
questions.subtext: Existing tools, workarounds, or manual processes.

questions.question: What makes yours different?
questions.subtext: Your unique angle or approach.

questions.question: Any constraints?
questions.subtext: Scope, timeline, tech requirements, design preferences.

2_data_model.label: Data Model
2_data_model.preContext: Based on your product definition, the AI already has context. These questions help refine the data model.

questions.question: What are the main things your app tracks?
questions.subtext: Think of these as the nouns in your product. Each becomes a database table.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Users, Projects, Tasks, Invoices, Messages

questions.question: How do these things relate to each other?
questions.subtext: Describe the connections. Use plain language — the AI will formalize it.
questions.placeholder: e.g., A User has many Projects. Each Project has many Tasks. Tasks can be assigned to Users.

questions.question: What important details does each thing have?
questions.subtext: List the key fields or properties for your main objects.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Projects need a name, description, status (active/archived), and creation date. Tasks need title, priority, due date, and assigned user.

questions.question: Any special data needs?
questions.subtext: Check any that apply to your product.

3_database.label: Database Design
3_database.preContext: The AI will generate a full schema from your data model. These questions capture your preferences.

questions.question: Do you have a database preference?
questions.subtext: Pick one, or let the AI recommend based on your data model.

options.label: PostgreSQL
options.description: Best all-around choice. JSON support, full-text search, rock solid.

options.label: MySQL
options.description: Widely supported. Good for straightforward relational data.

options.label: SQLite
options.description: Zero-config, file-based. Great for local-first or embedded apps.

options.label: MongoDB
options.description: Document store. Good for flexible/nested data structures.

options.label: Supabase
options.description: Postgres with built-in auth, real-time, and REST API.

options.label: Let AI decide
options.description: The AI will recommend based on your data model and use case.

questions.question: How much data do you expect?
questions.subtext: This helps the AI plan indexing and optimization.

options.label: Small
options.description: Hundreds to thousands of records. Personal tool or small team.

options.label: Medium
options.description: Tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands. Growing startup.

options.label: Large
options.description: Millions of records. Need to think about partitioning and caching.

options.label: Local Docker
options.description: Run locally during development, decide hosting later.

4_api_design.label: API Design
4_api_design.preContext: The AI generates API endpoints from your data model and features. These questions shape the API style.

options.label: REST
options.description: Standard HTTP endpoints. Most common, easy to understand.

options.label: GraphQL
options.description: Flexible queries. Good for complex frontends with varied data needs.

options.label: tRPC
options.description: End-to-end type safety with TypeScript. No separate API layer.

options.label: Let AI decide
options.description: Recommend based on the product type and data model.

questions.question: Any external APIs or services to integrate?
questions.subtext: List third-party services your app needs to talk to.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Stripe for payments, SendGrid for email, OpenAI API

5_stack.label: Programming Stack
5_stack.preContext: The AI will recommend a stack based on your product. Override any choices here.

questions.question: What's your technical background?
questions.subtext: This helps the AI pick tools you'll be comfortable with.

options.label: New to coding — pick the easiest path
Next.js
options.description: React with SSR, routing, and API routes built in.

questions.question: How do you want to style it?

options.label: Self-hosted VPS
options.description: Full control on your own server.

questions.question: What vibe should the app have?
questions.subtext: Pick words that describe the feeling. The AI will generate matching colors and typography.

questions.question: Any brand colors?
questions.subtext: Provide a primary color and the AI will generate a full palette. Or skip to let AI choose.

questions.question: Any apps you want it to look like?
questions.subtext: Name 1-3 apps whose design you admire. The AI will draw from their aesthetic.

options.label: Sidebar + Main Content
options.description: Classic dashboard layout. Sidebar navigation on the left.

options.label: Top Navigation + Content
options.description: Horizontal nav bar. Good for simpler apps.

options.label: Hybrid
options.description: Top bar for global nav, sidebar for section nav.

7_sections.label: Sections / Pages
7_sections.preContext: The AI will generate page specs from your product features. These questions help structure the UI.

questions.question: What are the main screens or pages?
questions.subtext: List every distinct page your app needs. Think of each entry in your navigation.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Dashboard, Projects, Settings, User Profile

questions.question: What's the first thing users see after login?
questions.subtext: This is your main dashboard or home screen.
questions.placeholder: e.g., A dashboard showing all active projects with progress bars and recent activity.

questions.question: Any complex interactions to call out?
questions.subtext: Drag-and-drop, real-time updates, multi-step wizards, etc.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Drag-and-drop kanban board for task management

questions.question: Which screens display a lot of data?
questions.subtext: Tables, charts, feeds — these need special attention for pagination, filtering, and performance.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Activity feed with infinite scroll, Usage analytics with charts

8_infrastructure.label: Infrastructure
8_infrastructure.preContext: The AI generates Docker configs and CI/CD from your stack choices. These questions fine-tune it.

options.label: Local + Staging + Production
options.description: Full pipeline with staging for testing.

9_export.label: Export
9_export.note: Stage 9 has no interview — it assembles and validates the SDP from all previous stages.

sharedComponents.StageInterviewWrapper: Wraps every stage editor. If stage has no data yet, shows the interview. If stage has data, shows the structured editor with a 'Re-interview' button.
sharedComponents.InterviewProgress: Shows completion across all 9 stages as a percentage. Visible in the pipeline stepper.
sharedComponents.SmartDefaults: Each stage interview pre-fills answers from previous stages. e.g., Stage 2 Data Model interview shows entities the AI inferred from Stage 1 features, letting the user confirm/edit instead of typing from scratch.
